articles.headline: Trump, at Putin’s Side, Questions U.S. Intelligence on 2016 Election
articles.snippet: At the end of their first summit meeting, Mr. Trump would not say whether he believes American intelligence agencies or Mr. Putin about Russian electoral interference.
articles.abstract: At the end of their first summit meeting, Mr. Trump would not say whether he believes American intelligence agencies or Mr. Putin about Russian electoral interference.
articles.lead_paragraph: HELSINKI, Finland — President Trump stood next to President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia on Monday and publicly challenged the conclusion of his own intelligence agencies that Moscow interfered in the 2016 presidential election, wrapping up what he called a “deeply productive” summit meeting with an extraordinary show of trust for a leader accused of attacking American democracy.

articles.headline: Latest Sign of China’s Slowdown: A Technology Cash Crunch
articles.snippet: Long awash in money, the country’s start-up scene has seen an unprecedented downturn. That could be a bad sign for the rest of the Chinese economy.
articles.abstract: Long awash in money, the country’s start-up scene has seen an unprecedented downturn. That could be a bad sign for the rest of the Chinese economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Wang Shidong and his two partners were still finishing graduate school two years ago when they raised $45 million in less than two months to start a venture capital fund. His wife, an elementary-school teacher in their home village, was “terrified” that he got to manage so much money, Mr. Wang said.

articles.headline: Republicans Rebuke Trump for Siding With Putin as Democrats Demand Action
articles.snippet: No Republican in Congress, however, pledged any particular action to punish President Trump, such as holding up his nominees, nor did any promise hearings or increased oversight.
articles.abstract: No Republican in Congress, however, pledged any particular action to punish President Trump, such as holding up his nominees, nor did any promise hearings or increased oversight.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For nearly two years, Republicans have watched uncomfortably, and often in silence, as President Trump has swatted away accusations that Russia interfered in the 2016 presidential race, attacked his own intelligence agencies and flattered President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia.
articles.byline: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg, Nicholas Fandos and Thomas Kaplan

articles.headline: Trump Sheds All Notions of How a President Should Conduct Himself Abroad
articles.snippet: Rather than defend America against those who would threaten it, he attacked his own citizens and institutions while hailing the leader of a hostile power.
articles.abstract: Rather than defend America against those who would threaten it, he attacked his own citizens and institutions while hailing the leader of a hostile power.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump, who gleefully defies the norms of presidential behavior, went somewhere in Helsinki, Finland, on Monday where none of his predecessors have ever gone: He accepted the explanation of a hostile foreign leader over the findings of his own intelligence agencies.

articles.headline: Mariia Butina, Who Sought ‘Back Channel’ Meeting for Trump and Putin, Is Charged as Russian Agent
articles.snippet: Ms. Butina was accused of trying to broker secret relationships with American politicians so Russia could influence American policies.
articles.abstract: Ms. Butina was accused of trying to broker secret relationships with American politicians so Russia could influence American policies.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A Russian woman who tried to broker a secret meeting between Donald J. Trump and the Russian president, Vladimir V. Putin, during the 2016 presidential campaign was charged Monday and accused of working with Americans to carry out a secret Russian effort to influence American politics.
articles.byline: By Matt Apuzzo, Katie Benner and Sharon LaFraniere

articles.headline: A Surprising Bid for Remington, and an Unsurprising Rejection
articles.snippet: The Navajo Nation made a cash offer for the gun maker, with the intention of pushing it toward “smart gun” technology.
articles.abstract: The Navajo Nation made a cash offer for the gun maker, with the intention of pushing it toward “smart gun” technology.
articles.lead_paragraph: This spring, I wrote a column suggesting someone should try to buy Remington, one of the country’s oldest and largest firearms makers, and transform the company into a model for advanced and responsible gun manufacturing.

articles.headline: E.U. Courts New Partners With Japan Trade Deal
articles.snippet: Hunting for free-trade deals in Asia and Latin America, the bloc is trying to compensate for lost business with the United States.
articles.abstract: Hunting for free-trade deals in Asia and Latin America, the bloc is trying to compensate for lost business with the United States.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Trump is inciting a trade war, undermining NATO and painting Europe as a foe. It’s no wonder, then, that the European Union is looking elsewhere for friends.

articles.headline: Australian Housing Costs Rival New York’s, but Boom May Be Ending
articles.snippet: Home prices in Sydney and Melbourne are dropping after an astonishing run-up, as the government moves to cool the market and households borrow too much.
articles.abstract: Home prices in Sydney and Melbourne are dropping after an astonishing run-up, as the government moves to cool the market and households borrow too much.
articles.lead_paragraph: SYDNEY — The home wasn’t perfect. The two-bedroom townhouse lacked parking and a backyard. Its proximity to a major road and a train station made for noisy evenings.
articles.byline: By Isabella Kwai and Adam Baidawi

articles.headline: For Republicans, ‘The Dam Has Broken.’ But for How Long?
articles.snippet: Never in the modern era has a president engendered such a wave of discussion about whether his real loyalty was to a foreign power over his own country.
articles.abstract: Never in the modern era has a president engendered such a wave of discussion about whether his real loyalty was to a foreign power over his own country.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After 17 months, three weeks and six days of Donald J. Trump’s tumultuous presidency, some of his fellow Republicans had finally had enough. “The dam has broken,” Senator Bob Corker, a Republican critic from Tennessee, said on Tuesday.
